prompt:
[INST] Character Info: Eleanor Tilney: Gentle and reserved, speaking in calm, thoughtful tones, always cautious with her words, maintaining propriety.
Miss Anne: Shy and thoughtful, speaking in soft, hesitant phrases, often unsure of her own opinions and desires.
Henry Tilney: Witty and charming, speaking in clever, playful tones, often using irony to convey deeper thoughts while maintaining a lighthearted demeanor.
Catherine Morland: Innocent and imaginative, speaking in lively, open tones, often lost in her romantic fantasies but always sincere in her feelings.


Dialogue History: Eleanor Tilney: Miss Morland, do not mind what he says; but have the goodness to satisfy me as to this dreadful riot.
Catherine Morland: Riot! What riot?
Henry Tilney: My dear Eleanor, the riot is only in your own brain. The confusion there is scandalous. Miss Morland has been talking of nothing more dreadful than a new publication which is shortly to come out, in three duodecimo volumes, two hundred and seventy-six pages in each, with a frontispiece to the first, of two tombstones and a lantern do you understand? And you, Miss Morland my stupid sister has mistaken all your clearest expressions. You talked of expected horrors in London and instead of instantly conceiving, as any rational creature would have done, that such words could relate only to a circulating library, she immediately pictured to herself a mob of three thousand men assembling in St. George s Fields, the Bank attacked, the Tower threatened, the streets of London flowing with blood, a detachment of the Twelfth Light Dragoons (the hopes of the nation) called up from Northampton to quell the insurgents, and the gallant Captain Frederick Tilney, in the moment of charging at the head of his troop, knocked off his horse by a brickbat from an upper window. Forgive her stupidity. The fears of the sister have added to the weakness of the woman; but she is by no means a simpleton in general.
Eleanor Tilney: And now, Henry, that you have made us understand each other, you may as well make Miss Morland understand yourself unless you mean to have her think you intolerably rude to your sister, and a great brute in your opinion of women in general. Miss Morland is not used to your odd ways.
Henry Tilney: I shall be most happy to make her better acquainted with them.
Eleanor Tilney: No doubt; but that is no explanation of the present.
Henry Tilney: What am I to do?
Eleanor Tilney: You know what you ought to do. Clear your character handsomely before her. Tell her that you think very highly of the understanding of women.
Henry Tilney: Miss Morland, I think very highly of the understanding of all the women in the world especially of those whoever they may be with whom I happen to be in company.
Eleanor Tilney: That is not enough. Be more serious.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Henry Tilney: Miss Morland, no one can think more highly of the understanding of women than I do. In my opinion, nature has given them so much that they never find it necessary to use more than half.

John Thorpe: Bold and boastful, speaking in exaggerated, self-important tones, always eager to impress others with his achievements.

Dialogue History: Catherine Morland: He _does_ look very hot, to be sure.
John Thorpe: Hot! He had not turned a hair till we came to Walcot Church; but look at his forehand; look at his loins; only see how he moves; that horse _cannot_ go less than ten miles an hour: tie his legs and he will get on. What do you think of my gig, Miss Morland? A neat one, is not it? Well hung; town-built; I have not had it a month. It was built for a Christchurch man, a friend of mine, a very good sort of fellow; he ran it a few weeks, till, I believe, it was convenient to have done with it. I happened just then to be looking out for some light thing of the kind, though I had pretty well determined on a curricle too; but I chanced to meet him on Magdalen Bridge, as he was driving into Oxford, last term:  Ah! Thorpe,  said he,  do you happen to want such a little thing as this? It is a capital one of the kind, but I am cursed tired of it.   Oh! D ,  said I;  I am your man; what do you ask?  And how much do you think he did, Miss Morland?
Catherine Morland: I am sure I cannot guess at all.
John Thorpe: Curricle-hung, you see; seat, trunk, sword-case, splashing-board, lamps, silver moulding, all you see complete; the iron-work as good as new, or better. He asked fifty guineas; I closed with him directly, threw down the money, and the carriage was mine.
Catherine Morland: And I am sure, I know so little of such things that I cannot judge whether it was cheap or dear.
John Thorpe: Neither one nor t other; I might have got it for less, I dare say; but I hate haggling, and poor Freeman wanted cash.
Catherine Morland: That was very good-natured of you,
John Thorpe: Oh! D   it, when one has the means of doing a kind thing by a friend, I hate to be pitiful.
John Thorpe: You will find, however, Miss Morland, it would be reckoned a cheap thing by some people, for I might have sold it for ten guineas more the next day; Jackson, of Oriel, bid me sixty at once; Morland was with me at the time.
James Morland: Yes, but you forget that your horse was included.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: John Thorpe: My horse! Oh, d   it! I would not sell my horse for a hundred. Are you fond of an open carriage, Miss Morland?

Dialogue History: Eleanor Tilney: My father only wanted me to answer a note,
Catherine Morland: Mr. Tilney!
Catherine Morland: Good God! How came you here? How came you up that staircase?
Henry Tilney: How came I up that staircase! Because it is my nearest way from the stable-yard to my own chamber; and why should I not come up it?
Henry Tilney: And may I not, in my turn, ask how _you_ came here? This passage is at least as extraordinary a road from the breakfast-parlour to your apartment, as that staircase can be from the stables to mine.
Catherine Morland: I have been, to see your mother s room.

Dialogue History: Catherine Morland: But why cannot Mr. Thorpe drive one of his other sisters? I dare say either of them would like to go.
John Thorpe: Thank ye, but I did not come to Bath to drive my sisters about, and look like a fool. No, if you do not go, d   me if I do. I only go for the sake of driving you.
Catherine Morland: That is a compliment which gives me no pleasure.
James Morland: I did not think you had been so obstinate, Catherine, you were not used to be so hard to persuade; you once were the kindest, best-tempered of my sisters.
Catherine Morland: I hope I am not less so now, but indeed I cannot go. If I am wrong, I am doing what I believe to be right.
Isabella Thorpe: I suspect, there is no great struggle.
John Thorpe: Well, I have settled the matter, and now we may all go tomorrow with a safe conscience. I have been to Miss Tilney, and made your excuses.
Catherine Morland: You have not!
John Thorpe: I have, upon my soul. Left her this moment. Told her you had sent me to say that, having just recollected a prior engagement of going to Clifton with us tomorrow, you could not have the pleasure of walking with her till Tuesday. She said very well, Tuesday was just as convenient to her; so there is an end of all our difficulties. A pretty good thought of mine hey?
Isabella Thorpe: A most heavenly thought indeed! Now, my sweet Catherine, all our distresses are over; you are honourably acquitted, and we shall have a most delightful party.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Catherine Morland: This will not do, I cannot submit to this. I must run after Miss Tilney directly and set her right.

Dialogue History: Catherine Morland: Then I will. Shall I go, Mrs. Allen?
Mrs. Allen: Just as you please, my dear.
Mrs. Allen: Well, my dear, suppose you go.
John Thorpe: Who is that girl who looked at you so hard as she went by?
Catherine Morland: Who? Where?
John Thorpe: On the right-hand pavement she must be almost out of sight now.
Catherine Morland: Stop, stop, Mr. Thorpe, it is Miss Tilney; it is indeed. How could you tell me they were gone? Stop, stop, I will get out this moment and go to them.
Catherine Morland: Pray, pray stop, Mr. Thorpe. I cannot go on. I will not go on. I must go back to Miss Tilney.
Catherine Morland: How could you deceive me so, Mr. Thorpe? How could you say that you saw them driving up the Lansdown Road? I would not have had it happen so for the world. They must think it so strange, so rude of me! To go by them, too, without saying a word! You do not know how vexed I am; I shall have no pleasure at Clifton, nor in anything else. I had rather, ten thousand times rather, get out now, and walk back to them. How could you say you saw them driving out in a phaeton?
James Morland: We had better go back, Thorpe; it is too late to go on today; your sister thinks so as well as I. We have been exactly an hour coming from Pulteney Street, very little more than seven miles; and, I suppose, we have at least eight more to go. It will never do. We set out a great deal too late. We had much better put it off till another day, and turn round.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: John Thorpe: It is all one to me,

Dialogue History: Catherine Morland: But it was not so bad as that, Isabella; there was no superciliousness; she was very civil.
Isabella Thorpe: Oh! Don t defend her! And then the brother, he, who had appeared so attached to you! Good heavens! Well, some people s feelings are incomprehensible. And so he hardly looked once at you the whole day?
Catherine Morland: I do not say so; but he did not seem in good spirits.
Isabella Thorpe: How contemptible! Of all things in the world inconstancy is my aversion. Let me entreat you never to think of him again, my dear Catherine; indeed he is unworthy of you.
Catherine Morland: Unworthy! I do not suppose he ever thinks of me.
Isabella Thorpe: That is exactly what I say; he never thinks of you. Such fickleness! Oh! How different to your brother and to mine! I really believe John has the most constant heart.
Catherine Morland: But as for General Tilney, I assure you it would be impossible for anybody to behave to me with greater civility and attention; it seemed to be his only care to entertain and make me happy.
Isabella Thorpe: Oh! I know no harm of him; I do not suspect him of pride. I believe he is a very gentleman-like man. John thinks very well of him, and John s judgment
Catherine Morland: Well, I shall see how they behave to me this evening; we shall meet them at the rooms.
Isabella Thorpe: And must I go?

 [/INST]
